abound:
**Abound** *(To abound, you may cast a nonland card that costs less than this from your hand without paying its mana cost.)*
• Abound is a keyword action. "Abound" means "You may cast a spell from your hand with a lesser mana value than this spell or permanent without paying its mana cost."
• If an triggered or activated ability instructs you to abound, use the mana value of the source of that ability to determine the mana value. If the ability somehow doesn't have a source, its mana value is 0 and you will be unable to cast a spell with a lesser mana value.
adjudicate:
**Adjudicate** *(Create a white Aura enchantment token with enchant creature and “Sacrifice this token: Untap enchanted creature” attached to target creature.)*
• Adjudicate is a keyword action that means "Create a white Aura enchantment token with enchant creature and 'Sacrifice this token: Untap enchanted creature' and attach it to target creature."
• If the token can't be attached to the target creature, for example if it has protection from enchantments, the token will never enter the battlefield.
aetherize:
**Aetherize** a card *(Create a token that's a copy of it, then exile that token.)*
• Aetherize is a keyword action. To aetherize a card, create a token that’s a copy of that card, then exile that token.
• Abilities that trigger as a result of that token entering or leaving the battlefield will be put on the stack after the token has left the battlefield, in the order that the controller of the triggers choose.
• If an effect such as Doubling Season causes you to create more than one token, all the tokens created by the aetherize action will be exiled.
affluent:
**Affluent** *(This creature gets +1/+1 and is affluent as long as you control an artifact.)*
• Affluent is a static ability. "Affluent" means "As long as you control an artifact, this creature gets +1/+1 and is affluent."
• Affluent is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the creature with affluent and other spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be affluent. Permanents stop being affluent immediately as their controller controls no artifacts. Affluent is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values.
alpha:
**Alpha** *(You may have this creature enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it. If you do, it becomes alpha and can only attack alone.)*
• Alpha is a static ability. “Alpha” means “You may have this permanent enter the battlefield with an additional +1/+1 counter on it. If you do, it becomes alpha and can only attack alone.”
• If a permanent has multiple instances of alpha, each works separately.
• If an alpha permanent loses its +1/+1 counter, it's still alpha and can still only attack alone.
• Alpha is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the alpha abilities and other spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become alpha. Once a permanent becomes alpha, it stays alpha until it leaves the battlefield. Alpha is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values.
animus:
Some lands have the subtype **Animus**, which have an ability that allows them to become a creature.
• Each Animus has a printed power and toughness, but it has these characteristics only if it's also a creature.
• If an Animus becomes a creature, it immediately has its printed power and toughness. Other effects, including the effect that makes it a creature, may modify these values or set them to different values.
archive:
**Archive** X *(As this enters the battlefield, shuffle the top X cards of your main library into a new face up library. Sacrifice this after the archived library is empty.)*
• Archive is a static ability of Study enchantments. "Archive X" means "As this permanent enters the battlefield, shuffle the top X cards of your starting library into an additional, face up, library."
• The additional library is referred to as "the archived library" by the Study with the archive ability that created it.
• Whenever state-based actions are checked, if a Study enchantment has a nonexistent archived library, its controller sacrifices it.
• If a card would be put into an archived library, that card is put in that library face up.
• If a Study card with archive leaves the battlefield, the archived library remains, but is no longer affected by any effects the Study provided.
• Cards are not revealed when they are put into a face up library. Cards can still become revealed even though the cards are already visible.
• If another player gains control of a Study, they will control any effects of the Study, but will not own the archived library. This means cards from the archived library can't go into that player's hand, graveyard, or library, and cards that player owns can't be put into the archived library. Effects of the Study may still allow them to manipulate or play the cards in that library.
arm:
**Arm** target creature *(Create a colorless Equipment artifact token with “Equipped creature gets +1/+0” and equip {2}, then attach it to that creature.)*
• To "arm" a creature, create a colorless Equipment artifact token with "Equipped creature gets +1/+0" and equip {2}, then attach that token to that creature.
• If that token can't be attached to that creature, the token is still created, but remains unattached.
ascend:
**Ascend** (cost) *((cost): Exile this creature, then return it to the battlefield transformed. Ascend only as a sorcery.)*
• Ascend is an activated ability. "Ascend (cost)" means "(cost): Exile this creature, then return it to the battlefield transformed. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery."
• If you somehow activate a permanents Ascend ability multiple times, only the first that tries to resolve will do anything.
assault:
**Assault** (cost) *(Whenever this attacks, if it has no +1/+1 counters on it, you may pay its assault cost to put a +1/+1 counter on it.)*
• Assault is a triggered ability of some creatures. "Assault (cost)" means "Whenever this creatures attacks, if it has no +1/+1 counters on it, you may pay (cost). If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on it."
• A creature "assaults" whenever its assault cost is paid, even if no +1/+1 counters are put on it for some reason.
beckon:
**Beckon** (creature type)—(cost) *((Cost): This noncreature Deity permanently becomes a (creature type) creature in addition to its other types.)*
• Beckon is an activated ability of Deity permanents. “Beckon (type)—(cost)” means “(Cost): If this permanent isn't a creature, it becomes a (type) creature in addition to its other types.”
• A beckon effect lasts indefinitely.
• If a Deity somehow becomes a noncreature again, its beckon ability can be reactivated.
• If a Deity is a creature, its beckon ability will have no affect, even if it's not the creature type it would become.
bloodprice:
**Bloodprice** (cost) *(You may cast this card by sacrificing a creature and paying its bloodprice.)*
• Bloodprice is a static ability that functions while the spell with bloodprice is on the stack. "Bloodprice (cost)" means "You may cast this spell by paying (cost) and sacrificing a creature rather than paying its mana cost.
bounty:
**Post a bounty** on target creature *(Put a bounty counter on that creature. It has “When this creature dies, each opponent draws a card” as long as it has a bounty counter on it.)*
• To "post a bounty" on a permanent means to put a bounty counter on that permanent. For as long as that permanent has a bounty counter on it, it has "When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each opponent draws a card."
• A new triggered ability is gained each time a bounty is placed on a permanent.
• The permanent will only gain the ability once per time a bounty is posted, even if it would get more than one bounty counter from it, such as through Doubling Season.
• If some bounty counters are removed but not all of them, the permanent will still have the ability as many times as a bounty was posted on it.
cackle:
(this creature) **cackles**. *(Put a menace counter on it. If it already has menace, it deals 1 damage to each opponent instead.)*
• “Cackle” means “If this creature has menace, it deals 1 damage to each opponent. Otherwise, put a menace counter on it.”
cadence:
**Cadence** *(Whenever you cast a spell, if its mana value is greater than this creature's power, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature.)*
• Cadence is a triggered ability of some creatures. "Cadence" means "Whenever you cast a spell, if its mana value is greater than this creature's power, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature."
• Cadence will check the creature's power as it triggers and as it tries to resolve. If that creature's power is greater than or equal to that spell's mana value at either point, the ability won't resolve.
• If a permanent with cadence isn't a creature, the cadence ability will trigger whenever you cast a spell with mana value greater than 0.
catalyze:
**Catalyze** *(The next spell you cast this turn costs {1} less to cast.)*
• Certain spells and abilities cause a player to catalyze. The next spell that player casts this turn costs {1} less to cast.
• Multiple instances of catalyze stack, but will all apply to the same spell, even if the spell costs less than the number of active catalyzes.
chosen:
**Chosen one** *({W}{U}{B}{R}{G}: Transform this permanent.)*
• Chosen one is an activated ability of some permanents. "Chosen one" means "{W}{U}{B}{R}{G}: Transform this permanent."
coalesce:
**Coalesce** (cost) *(You may cast this from your graveyard for (cost). If you do, put it onto the battlefield as a Horror creature after it resolves. Exile it if it would leave the battlefield or not resolve.)*
• Coalesce appears on Revelation cards. It represents three static abilities: one that functions while the card is in a player's graveyard and two that functions while the card is on the stack. "Coalesce (cost)" means "You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying (cost) rather than paying its mana cost," "If the coalesce cost was paid, put this card onto the battlefield as a Horror creature. If it would leave the battlefield, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else," and "If the coalesce cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else anytime it would leave the stack except being put onto the battlefield with its coalesce ability."
conjure:
**Conjure** (cost) *(You may cast this creature from your graveyard for its conjure cost. If you do, exile it when it enters the battlefield or if it would leave the battlefield.)*
• Conjure represents a static ability that functions while the card with conjure is in a graveyard, a triggered ability that functions on the battlefield, and a static ability that functions on the battlefield. "Conjure (cost)" means "You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying (cost) rather than paying its mana cost.", "When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its conjure cost was paid, its controller exiles it.", and "If this creature would leave the battlefield, if its conjure cost was paid, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else." Paying a card's conjure cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs.
• If multiple abilities trigger simultaneously, players decide the order triggers they control are put on the stack in active player/non-active player order.
consume:
**Consume** *(To consume, sacrifice another creature or exile a creature card from your graveyard.)*
• Consume is a keyword action. To have a creature consume, sacrifice a creature other than the creature consuming, or exile a creature card from your graveyard.
• The creature that consumed may have linked abilities related to the cards it consumed.
• If a creature has moved to the graveyard by the time its consume ability resolves, it can exile the same card to consume.
cripple:
**Cripple** (cost) *(You may cast this spell for its cripple cost if an opponent has lost life this turn.)*
• Cripple is a static ability that functions while the card with cripple is on the stack. "Cripple (cost)" means "You may pay (cost) rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell if an opponent lost life this turn."
• Cripple only cares if an opponent lost life. If those opponents gained the life back, you can still cast a spell for its cripple cost. If your opponents have only lost glory counters and not life, you can't cast a spell for its cripple cost.
cursed:
**Cursed** *(A player with a Curse attached to them is cursed.)*
• A player is "cursed" if they are being enchanted by a Curse Aura.
• Auras enchanting a player without the Curse subtype have no bearing on if a player is cursed.
deception:
**Deception** (cost) *((cost), Return an unblocked attacker you control to hand: Put this card onto the battlefield from your hand tapped and attacking.)*
• Deception is an activated ability that functions only while the card with deception is in a player's hand. "Deception (cost)" means "(cost), Reveal this card from your hand, Return an unblocked attacking creature you control to its owner’s hand: Put this card onto the battlefield from your hand tapped and attacking."
• The card with deception remains revealed from the time the ability is announced until the ability leaves the stack.
• A deception ability may be activated only while a creature on the battlefield is unblocked (after blockers are declared). The creature with deception is put onto the battlefield unblocked. It will be attacking the same player or planeswalker as the creature that was returned to its owner's hand.
defiant:
**Defiant** *(Whenever this creature takes damage, if it survives and wasn't defiant, put a +1/+1 counter on it and it becomes defiant.)*
• Defiant is a triggered ability of some creatures. "Defiant" means "Whenever this creature is dealt damage, if it isn't defiant, put a +1/+1 counter on it and it becomes defiant.
desecrate:
**Desecrate** *(When this creature enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice an artifact or land.)*
• Desecrate is a triggered ability. "Desecrate" means "When this creature enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice an artifact or land."
• A creature with desecrate "desecrates a permanent" when the controller of the desecrate ability sacrifices a permanent as that ability resolves.
discovery:
Discoveries are enchantments that act similarly to Sagas, but on their last counter (usually the third) unlock a static ability, rather than trigger another ability and sacrifice itself.
*(As this Discovery enters and after your draw step, add a progress counter. Stop after you've discovered.)*
• As a Discovery enters the battlefield, its controller puts a progress counter on it.
• As a player’s precombat main phase begins, that player puts a progress counter on each Discovery they control with a number of progress counters on it fewer than its final progress number. This turn-based action doesn’t use the stack.
• A Discovery’s final progress number is the greatest value among progress abilities it has plus 1. If a Discovery somehow has no progress abilities, its final progress number is 1.
• A progress symbol is a keyword ability that represents a static or triggered ability referred to as a progress ability.
• A progress symbol includes a Roman numeral, indicated here as "{rN}," or a bottle symbol, indicated here as "{Discovery}." The numeral I represents 1, II represents 2, III represents 3, and so on.
• "{rN}—[Effect]" means "When one or more progress counters are put onto this Discovery, if the number of progress counters on it was less than N and became at least N, [effect]."
• "{rN1}, {rN2}—[Effect]" means the same as "{rN1}—[Effect]" and "{rN2}—[Effect]."
• "{Discovery}—[Abilities]" means "As long as this Discovery has a number of progress counters on it greater than or equal to its final progress number, it has '[abilities]'."
distorted:
**Distorted** *(This creature can be blocked by tapped creatures but not untapped creatures.)*
• Distorted is an evasion ability. A creature with distorted can't be blocked by untapped creatures. Tapped creatures can block creatures with distorted. This is an exception to rule 509.1a
• A creature with distorted can still only block creatures without distorted if it is untapped.
embattled:
**Embattled** *(A creature is embattled if it has a counter on it or has a permanent you control attached to it.)*
• A creature is "embattled" if that creature has a counter on it or that creature has a permanent with the same controller attached to it.
embellish:
**Embellish** (cost) *(If you cast this spell for (cost), create a 1/1 blue Thopter artifact creature token with flying when it enters the battlefield.)*
• Embellish represents a static ability that functions while the card with embellish is on the stack and a triggered ability that functions on the battlefield, and one which may create a delayed triggered ability. "Embellish (cost)" means "You may cast this card by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost," and "When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its embellish cost was paid, create a 1/1 blue Thopter artifact creature token with flying."
embody:
**Embody** *(Enchanted creature is a copy of this card except for its types.)*
• "Embody" means "Enchanted creature is a copy of this Persona except for its types, supertypes, and subtypes.
• If a legendary Persona is enchanting a legendary creature, they will be affected by the legend rule.
encourage:
**Encourage** *({T}: Another target creature you control gets +1/+1 until end of turn. Encourage only as a sorcery.)*
• Encourage is an activated ability. “Encourage” means “{T}: Another target creature you control gets +1/+1 until end of turn. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.”
• A creature with encourage "encourages a creature" and that creature "becomes encouraged" as the encourage ability resolves.
engage:
**Engage** *(This creature must be blocked each combat if able.)*
• Engage is a static ability of some creatures. "Engage" means "This creature must be blocked each combat if able."
• This gets difficult when paired with menace. If there are multiple requirements on how creatures can block, the maximum amount of requirements must be obeyed.
***Example:*** *Untouched Duelist has engage and menace. You attack with an Untouched Duelist and two creatures with engage. Your opponent has two creatures. Blocking only the Untouched Duelist would leave two unfilled requirements, while blocking the other two engage creatures would leave one unfilled requirement, so the other two engage creatures must be blocked.*
engorge:
**Engorge** X *(As this enters the battlefield, mill X cards, then exile a card from among the milled cards.)*
• Engorge is a static ability. "Engorge" means "As this creature enters the battlefield, put the top three cards of your library into your graveyard, then exile exactly one card put into your graveyard this way."
• A creature with engorge may refer to the card exiled this way as "the card it engorged."
enspirit:
**Enspirit** *(As you cast this spell, you may exile a nonenchantment creature you control until this leaves the battlefield or fails to resolve. Reduce this spell's cost by the exiled card's mana value.)*
• Enspirit represents two static abilities, one that functions while the spell with enspirit is on the stack and another that functions both while it's on the stack and while it's on the battlefield.  "Enspirit" means "As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may exile a nonenchantment creature you control until this spell is put from the stack into a zone other than the battlefield or the permanent this spell becomes leaves the battlefield" and "If you chose to pay this spell's additional cost, its total cost is reduced by an amount of generic mana equal to the exiled card's mana value." Paying a spell's enspirit cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2f–h.
• A creature "becomes enspirited" when it's exiled to pay a spell's enspirit cost. Abilities that trigger when a creature becomes enspirited are leaves-the-battlefield abilities.
erratic:
**Erratic** *(When this creature dies, reveal the top four cards of your library. Put a creature card that costs less than this revealed this way onto the battlefield and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.)*
• Erratic is a triggered ability. "Erratic" means "When this creature dies, reveal the top four cards of your library. Put a creature card revealed this way whose mana value is less than this card's mana value onto the battlefield and the rest of the cards on the bottom of your library in any order."
• This ability will trigger even if the permanent is not a creature when it is put into a graveyard from the battlefield.
eureka:
**Eureka!** *(At the beginning of each end step, you get a research counter if you cast a spell this turn. Then if you have eight or more research counters, remove them and create a Masterpiece token of your choice.)*
• Eureka! is a triggered ability of some permanents. "Eureka!" means "At the beginning of each end step, you get a research counter if you cast a spell this turn. Then if you have eight or more research counters, you lose all research counters, then create your choice of Cultivating Spheres, Mirror of Possibilities, and Thrice-Folded Lotus."
• Cultivating Spheres is a colorless Masterpiece artifact token with "At the beginning of your draw step, draw an additional card" and "You may play an additional land on each of your turns."
• Mirror of Possibilities is a colorless Masterpiece artifact token with "Whenever you cast an instant or sorcery spell, you may pay {3}. If you do, copy it. You may choose new targets for the copy" and "Whenever a nontoken creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may pay {3}. If you do, create a token that’s a copy of it."
• Thrice-Folded Lotus is a colorless Masterpiece artifact token with "{T}: Add three mana of any one color" and "{3}, {T}: Thrice-Folded Lotus deals 3 damage to any target."
• Eureka! checks if you cast a spell this turn when the ability resolves. This means you can cast a spell in response to the trigger to get a counter.
excess:
**Excess damage** is the amount of damage being dealt to a creature in excess of the lethal damage that can be marked on it, to a planeswalker in excess of the number of loyalty counters it has, to a planeswalker creature equal to the greater value of those, or a player in excess of their life total.
• Effects that prevent or modify damage are done before checking excess damage.
• Effects that modify the affects of damage, but not the damage directly, such as indestructible or Platinum Angel, have no effect on calculating excess damage.
• All but 1 damage dealt by a source with deathtouch to a creature is excess damage.
experience:
**Experience** *(Whenever this creature attacks, if it has fewer than three +1/+1 counters on it, put a +1/+1 counter on it.)*
• Experience is a triggered ability. "Experience" means "Whenever this creature attacks, if it has two or fewer +1/+1 counters on it, put a +1/+1 counter on it."
• If a creature with experience has three or more +1/+1 counters on it as the ability tries to resolve, it will have no effect.
extort:
**Extort** *(Whenever you cast a spell, you may pay {W/B}. If you do, each opponent loses 1 life and you gain that much life.)*
• Extort is a triggered ability. "Extort" means "Whenever you cast a spell, you may pay (W/B). If you do, each opponent loses 1 life and you gain life equal to the total life lost this way."
• If a permanent has multiple instances of extort, each triggers separately.
• A permanent "extorts" a spell whenever its extort ability is paid, and a spell is "extorted" when an extort ability it triggered is paid. This can occur many times per permanent or spell. Any abilities that trigger due to this payment occur after the life loss and gain.
fabled:
**Fabled** (cost) *(Then if you cast this for its fabled cost, put it onto the battlefield transformed attached to that player.)*
• Fabled appears on some instants and sorceries with a single target. It represents a static ability while the spell with fabled is on the stack and a spell ability. "Fabled (cost)" means "You may pay (cost) rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell." and "If this spell's fabled cost was paid, put this card onto the battlefield transformed and attached to that creature, player, or planeswalker."
• The Aura or Equipment that spell becomes will always try to attach to the target of the first ability of the card.
• If the targeted creature or player is an illegal target for the Aura or Equipment side of a card with fabled, such as a creature with protection from artifacts and enchantments, the card with fabled will not enter the battlefield and instead be put directly into its owner's graveyard from the stack.
fateseal:
**Fateseal** X *(Look at the top X cards of an opponent's library, then put any number on the bottom and the rest on top in any order.)*
• To fateseal N means to look at the top N cards of an opponent’s library, put any number of them on the bottom of that library in any order and the rest on top of that library in any order.
fealty:
**Fealty** to (type)s *(Each (type) you control counts towards your fealty to (type)s.)*
• A player's fealty to (type) is equal to the number of permanents of that type they control.
first:
**First mate** — [condition] *(If this card outside the game is your chosen first mate, you may swap it with a card in your opening hand.)*
• First mate is a keyword ability and a variant of the companion ability that functions outside the game. It’s written as “First mate—[Condition].”
• Before the game begins, you may reveal one card you own from outside the game with a companion ability whose condition is fulfilled by your starting deck.
• Once the mulligan process is complete, a player may exchange a card in their hand and their first mate card from outside the game. The card put outside the game is not made public to other players.
forebode:
**forebode** *(Create a tapped colorless Omen artifact token with “T, Discard a card, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.”)*
• To forebode, create a tapped colorless Omen artifact token with “T, Discard a card, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.”
frenzy:
**Frenzy** X *(Whenever this creature attacks and isn't blocked, it gets +X/+0 until end of turn.)*
• Frenzy is a triggered ability. "Frenzy N" means "Whenever this creature attacks and isn't blocked, it gets +N/+0 until end of turn."
• If a creature has multiple instances of frenzy, each triggers separately.
• Frenzy and other 'attacks and isn't blocked' abilities only trigger after blockers have been declared.
gestalt:
**Gestalt** *(If this or another creature you control would enter the battlefield, you may instead merge it over or under the one in play. They become the permanent on top plus all abilities from under it.)*
• Gestalt represents two static abilities, one that functions as the card with gestalt is entering the battlefield, and one that functions while the card with gestalt is on the battlefield. "Gestalt" means "If this card would enter the battlefield, instead you may merge it with a creature you control. It becomes a gestalt permanent." and "If a creature would enter the battlefield under your control, you may merge it with this permanent. It becomes a gestalt permanent."
• A gestalt permanent has all abilities of each card and token that represents it. Its other characteristics are derived from the topmost card or token.
• Any effect that refers to or modifies the spell entering the battlefield as a gestalt permanent refers to or modifies the gestalt permanent it merges with as it resolves.
germinate:
**Germinate** *(Put a +1/+1 counter on a creature or create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token.)*
• "Germinate" means "You may put a +1/+1 counter on a creature. If you don't, create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token."
• If you are unable to put counters on a creature, creating the token isn't optional.
glory:
You get a **glory counter** *(You lose glory counters before life. A player with ten or more glory counters wins the game.)*
• If a player has ten or more glory counters, they wins the game the next time a player would receive priority.
• For each 1 life a player with one or more glory counters would lose, that player removes a glory counter from themselves instead. This applies to any source of life loss, including paying life and your life total being set to a number lower than it currently is.
• A player is "glorious" if they have one or more glory counters.
• If multiple effects are attempting to replace a player losing life, that player decides what order the effects apply in.
harmon:
**Harmonize** *(Trigger up to one harmony of one permanent you control.)*
• A harmony ability is a special kind of triggered ability that only triggers when chosen as part of the harmonize keyword action. "Harmony — [Effect]" means "Whenever you harmonize, if you choose this ability, [effect]."
• Harmonize is a keyword action. "Harmonize" means "Choose up to one harmony ability of a permanent you control." Choosing an ability this way causes that ability to trigger.
harness:
**Harness** *(You may tap a creature you control as you cast this spell. If you do, reduce this spell’s mana cost by that creature’s power.)*
• "Harness" means "As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap an untapped creature you control. This spell costs {X} less to cast, where X is that creature's power."
• The creature tapped this way "harnesses" that spell.
harvest:
**Harvest** *(You may tap any number of creatures you control as you cast this spell. If you do, reduce this spell's mana cost by their total power.)*
• "Harvest" means "As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap any number of untapped creatures you control. This spell costs {X} less to cast, where X is the total power of creature's tapped this way."
heretic:
**Heretic** *(Whenever you cast a spell that doesn't share a color with this creature, it gets +1/+1 until end of turn.)*
• Heretic is a triggered ability found on some creatures. "Heretic" means "Whenever you cast a spell that doesn't share a color with this creature, this creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn."
• Heretic only checks the color of the creature and the spell when the spell is cast. If either changes color afterwards, it will be too late to gain or negate the effect.
• Colorless spells will always trigger heretic, because they don't share a color with anything.
idolize:
**Idolize** *(To idolize, create a colorless Idol artifact token with “{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature. Activate only as a sorcery.”)*
• Idolize is an keyword action that means "Create a colorless Idol artifact token with '{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature. Activate only as a sorcery.'"
• An Idol can still be sacrificed if it somehow stops being an artifact.
infiltrate:
**Infiltrate** *(Whenever one or more attacking creatures you control aren't blocked, this creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.)*
• Infiltrate is a triggered ability. "Infiltrate" means "Whenever one or more creatures you control attack and aren't blocked, this creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn."
• If a creature has multiple instances of infiltrate, each triggers separately.
• The creature will get +1/+1 until end of turn even if it is not attacking.
• Infiltrate and other 'attacks and isn't blocked' abilities only trigger after blockers have been declared.
inscribe:
**Inscribe** (cost) *((cost): Exile this card from your hand inscribed on a creature you control. Whenever that creature attacks, its controller may cast a copy of the inscribed card without paying its mana cost. Inscribe only as a sorcery.)*
• Inscribe represents an activated ability that functions while the card with inscribe is in its owner's hand and a static ability that functions while the card with inscribe is in the exile zone. "Inscribe (cost)" means "(cost): Exile this card from your hand inscribed on a creature you control. Activate this ability only at any time you could cast a sorcery." and "The creature this card is inscribed onto has 'Whenever this creature attacks, you may copy the inscribed card and you may cast the copy without paying its mana cost.'"
• If an inscribed card somehow leaves exile, it will no longer be inscribed on that creature.
• Cards with this ability have the subtype Inscription.
• If you copy an inscribe ability you control, only one of them will be able to exile the card from your hand and will the rest will do nothing.
• If you gain control of or copy an inscribe ability of a card you don't own, you will be unable to exile the card and the ability will do nothing.
invigorate:
**Invigorate** X *(Choose a creature with the least power among creatures you control and put X +1/+1 counters on it.)*
• Invigorate N is a keyword action that means "Choose a creature you control with the least power or tied for the least power among creatures you control. Put N +1/+1 counters on that creature."
journey:
**Journey** *(Exile the top card of your library face up. Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to an opponent, put a journeyed card you own into your hand.)*
• To journey, exile the top card of your library face up and it becomes journeyed.
• Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to an opponent, put a journeyed card you own from exile into your hand.
kindle:
**Kindle** X—(cost) *((cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create X 1/1 colorless Elemental creature tokens. Kindle only as a sorcery.)*
• Kindle is an activated ability that functions while the card with kindle is in a graveyard. "Kindle X—(cost)" means "(cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create X 1/1 colorless Elemental creature tokens. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery."
leitmotif:
**Leitmotif** *(If you cast this spell from your hand, exile it as it resolves. When you next cast a spell that shares a color with this card, you may cast this from exile without paying its mana cost.)*
• Leitmotif appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents a static ability that functions while the spell is on the stack and may create a delayed triggered ability. "Leitmotif" means "If this spell was cast from your hand, instead of putting it into your graveyard as it resolves, exile it and, when you cast a spell that shares a color with this card, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost."
make:
**Make** X Card Names *(Bring X cards named Card Name into the game.)*
• Make is a keyword action. "Make (Card Name)" means "Bring a card named Card Name into the game."
• The rest of the spell effect or ability will determine what zone the new card enters.
• Cards made this way are not moved from any zone or a player's sideboard. 
• Cards made this way are cards and not tokens, even if they are represented by token or checklists cards.
• When a game ends, cards that were made during that game are removed from decks.
• When a game is restarted, cards that were made during that game remain in decks.
mark:
**Mark** *(Whenever this creature attacks, mark target creature until end of turn.)*
• Mark is a triggered ability of some creatures. "Mark" means "Whenever this creature attacks, target creature becomes marked until end of turn."
• Marked is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become marked.
memento:
**Memento** (cost) *(You may cast this from your graveyard for (cost). If you do, put it onto the battlefield transformed after it resolves. Exile it if it would leave the battlefield or not resolve.)*
• Memento appears on some double-faced cards. It represents three static abilities: one that functions while the card with memento is in a player's graveyard and two that function while the spell with memento is on the stack. "Memento (cost)" means "You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying (cost) rather than paying its mana cost," "If this memento cost was paid, put this card onto the battlefield transformed. If it would leave the battlefield, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else," and "If the memento cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else anytime it would leave the stack except being put onto the battlefield with its memento ability."
metamorph:
**Metamorph** (cost) *(You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up and cast it at any time for its metamorph cost.)*
• Metamorph is a variant of the morph ability. "Metamorph (cost)" means "You may cast this card as a 2/2 face-down creature with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost by paying {3} rather than paying its mana cost." and "As this permanent is turned face up, cast it without paying its mana cost if its metamorph cost was paid to turn it face up."
• There is never a time where a face up card with metamorph is on the battlefield.
mimic:
**Mimic** (cost) *((Cost): This takes the shape of your choice. Mimic only as a sorcery.)*
• Mimic is an activated ability. “Mimic (cost)” means “(Cost): Choose a number. Activate only as a sorcery.”
• Any number can be chosen. If the permanent does not have a shape associated with that number, it will only have its base characteristics.
• Some leveler cards with the ability mimic use a variant level symbol, which is labeled with the word SHAPE insteead of LEVEL, and do not use counters.
• “{SHAPE N} [Abilities] [P/T]” means “As long as N was chosen the last time this permanent's mimic ability resolved, it has base power and toughness [P/T]” and it has [abilities].”
mirage:
**Mirage** (cost) *(You may cast this spell as though it had flash for its mirage cost. If you do, sacrifice it at the beginning of the next cleanup step.)*
• Mirage represents two static abilities, one that functions while the card with mirage is on the stack, and one which may create a delayed triggered ability. "Mirage (cost)" means "You may cast this card as though it had flash by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost," and "If this spell's mirage cost was paid, sacrifice the permanent this spell becomes at the beginning of the next cleanup step."
• Permanents with mirage will leave the battlefield after damage is removed from permanents and 'until end of turn' and 'this turn' effects end.
• If the triggered ability of mirage is countered, it will not trigger again.
motivate:
**Motivate** X *(When this creature enters the battlefield, you may motivate target creature with less power than this by putting X +1/+1 counters on it.)*
• Motivate is a trigged ability. "Motivate N" means "When this creature enters the battlefield, you may put N +1/+1 counters on target creature with power less than this creature's power."
• A creature with motivate "motivates a creature" and that creature "becomes motivated" when the controller of the motivate ability puts +1/+1 counters on a creature as that ability resolves.
mystery:
**Mystery Cards** *(As you complete a condition, decode it. After all are decoded, you solve the mystery and transform this.)*
• Each Mystery card is a double-faced card. The front face has a striated textbox containing a number of mystery symbols. Its illustration is  vertically oriented on the right side of the card, and its typeline is along the bottom of the card. The back face is a standard Magic card.
• A mystery symbol is a keyword ability that represents a static ability.
• A mystery symbol includes a magnifying glass symbol, indicated here as {mg}.
• {mg}—[Condition] means As [condition], decode this ability.
• Decode has no rules meaning, and is just a designation that the ability's condition has been met.
• If a mystery card has one or more mystery abilities and each of those abilities is decoded, it transforms. This state-based action doesn't use the stack.
nourish:
**Nourish** X *(To nourish X, either put X +1/+1 counters on this creature or create X 1/1 white Citizen creature tokens.)*
• "Nourish N" means "You may put N +1/+1 counters on this permanent. If you don't, create N 1/1 white Citizen creature tokens."
• If you are unable to put counters on the permanent, creating the tokens isn't optional.
orchestrate:
**Orchestrate** (cost) *(You may exile this card from your hand anytime you could cast a sorcery for its orchestrate cost. The next time you cast a spell, cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.)*
• Orchestrate represents a static ability of a card in your hand that creates a delayed triggered ability. "Orchestrate (cost)" means "At any time you could cast a sorcery, you may pay (cost) and exile this card from your hand. If you do, when you cast your next spell, cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost."
• Exiling a card for its orchestrate cost is a special action and can't be countered.
• If the triggered ability created by orchestrate is countered, the card will remain in exile and the ability allowing you to cast it won't retrigger.
paranoia:
**Paranoia** (cost) *(You may cast this spell for its paranoia cost when a permanent you control leaves the battlefield.)*
• Paranoia is a static ability linked to a triggered ability that functions while the card with paranoia is in a player's hand or on the stack. "Paranoia (cost)" means "You may reveal this card from your hand as a permanent you control leaves the battlefield. When you reveal this card this way, you may cast it by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost."
• Casting a spell with paranoia ignores all normal timing restrictions for the spell. Effects can still prevent players from casting the spell or increase the mana cost to cast it.
• The triggered ability that allows you to cast a spell for its paranoia cost can be countered.
• If a spell is cast for its paranoia cost, other alternate mana costs can't be paid, but other additional costs can be.
• If a creature leaves the battlefield as part of a cost, unless it was to pay for a mana ability, paranoia will trigger before that spell or ability resolves.
permutate:
**Permutate** *(You may remove a counter from a creature you control. If you do, put two +1/+1 counters on a different creature you control.)*
• Permutate is a keyword action. To permutate, you may remove a counter from a creature you control. If you do, put two +1/+1 counters on a different creature you control.
• You can permutate if you only control one creature, but you won't be able to put +1/+1 counters on anything.
persevere:
**Perseveres** *(A creature perseveres when it survives damage.)*
• After damage is dealt to a creature, that creature perseveres if it is still on the battlefield.
• State-based actions are checked multiple times, so if a creature's toughness becomes less than the damage marked on it due to state-based actions, it will not persevere.
***Example:*** *Interan Soothsayer reads "Interan Soothsayer gets +1/+1 for each other green creature you control." You control a 1/1 green Saproling and an Interan Soothsayer. If 2 damage is dealt to each creature, the Saproling will be destoyed, then state-based actions will be checked again and Soothsayer will be destroyed and will not persevere.*
poisonous:
**Poisonous** X *(Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, that player gets X poison counters.)*
• Poisonous is a triggered ability. "Poisonous N" means "Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, that player gets N poison counters."
• A player with 10 or more poison counters loses the game.
• If a creature has multiple instances of poisonous, each triggers separately.
pressure:
**Pressure** *(You may cast this spell for its pressure cost if there are seven or more cards in your graveyard.)*
• Pressure is a static ability that functions while the spell with surge is on the stack. “Pressure (cost)” means “You may pay (cost) rather than pay this spell’s mana cost as you cast this spell if there are seven or more cards in your graveyard.”
• The final cost of a spell is locked in before costs are paid, meaning a spell can be cast for its pressure cost while also having an additional cost that exiles cards from its controller's graveyard that would result in having fewer than seven cards in it.
primal:
**Primal** (cost) *(During your turn, you may cast this spell for (cost) instead of playing a land.)*
• Primal is a static ability that functions while the spell with primal is on the stack. "Primal (cost)" means "During your turn, you may cast this spell for (cost) rather than pay this spell's mana cost. If you do, casting this spell also counts as playing a land."
• The spell with primal is still cast. It is not a special action, it only counts as playing a land when determining if a player can play a land this turn.
• A spell can be cast for its primal cost at any point during a player's turn, as long as the number of lands that player can play this turn is greater than the number of lands they has already played this turn, even if timing restrictions would normally prevent playing a land. This means a spell may be cast for its primal cost during its owner's upkeep or end step, but not during another player's turn, or during a turn where lands can't be played.
• Additional land plays allow you to play additional cards for their primal cost in a turn.
profit:
**Profit** *(To profit, create a colorless Gold artifact token with “Sacrifice this artifact: Add one mana of any color.”)*
• To profit, create a colorless Gold artifact token with "Sacrifice this artifact: Add one mana of any color."
prophecy:
**Prophecy** (cost) *(Once each turn, you may exile a card with prophecy as you reveal it. When you do, you may cast it for its prophecy cost as long as it's exiled.)*
• Prophecy is a keyword that represents a static ability linked to a triggered ability. "Prophecy (cost)" means "As you reveal this card from a hidden zone, you may exile it if you haven't exiled a card with its prophecy ability this turn." and "When you exile this card with its prophecy ability, you may cast it for (cost) rather than paying its mana cost as long as it remains exiled."
• If you reveal multiple cards with prophecy simultaneously, you will only be able to exile up to one.
• When a card is exiled with its prophecy ability, any relevant information about it is retained by the revealing effect, but the card is exiled and becomes a new object. For example, Cursed Scroll will know the name of a card with prophecy, but it can't be put into a Fact or Fiction pile or chosen during the resolution of Gifts Ungiven.
• A card can't be cast for its prophecy cost if it was exiled by an effect other than its prophecy ability.
• The triggered ability that allows you to cast a card with prophecy from exile can be countered.
purge:
**Purge** *(Exile two cards that share a type from graveyards. If you do, draw a card.)*
• Purge is a keyword action that means "Exile two cards that share a card type from graveyards. If you exile two cards this way, draw a card."
quickdraw:
**Quickdraw** (cost) *(When a creature you control blocks or becomes blocked, you may cast this spell for (cost).)*
• Quickdraw is a static ability linked to a triggered ability that functions while the card with quickdraw is in a player's hand or on the stack. "Quickdraw (cost)" means "You may reveal this card from your hand as a creature you control blocks or becomes blocked. When you reveal this card this way, you may cast it by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost."
• Casting a spell with quickdraw ignores all normal timing restrictions for the spell. Effects can still prevent players from casting the spell or increase the mana cost to cast it.
• The triggered ability that allows you to cast a spell for its quickdraw cost can be countered.
• If a spell is cast for its quickdraw cost, other alternate mana costs can't be paid, but other additional costs can be.
realm:
**Realm Cards** *(Activate each ability only once as a sorcery. You gain the realm's favor after activating them all.)*
• Each Realm card has a striated textbox containing a number of realm abilities and a favor symbol. Its illustration is vertically oriented on the right side of the card, and its typeline is along the bottom of the card.
• A realm ability is an activated ability printed on a Realm card that isn't part of a favor symbol.
• A realm ability can be activated only once. This is true even if the permanent with the realm ability is not a Realm.
• A favor symbol is a keyword ability that represents a static ability,  which gives the Realm another ability referred to as a favor ability.
• A favor symbol includes a laurels symbol, indicated here as {fL}.
• {fL}—[Ability] means As long as you have activated each of this permanent's realm abilities, it has [ability].
• If a permanent somehow has a favor symbol but no realm abilities, it will have the favor ability.
reappropriate:
**Reappropriate** *(To reappropriate, exile exactly two cards from your hand and/or graveyard.)*
• To reappropriate, exile exactly two cards from your hand and/or graveyard.
• If you are instructed to reappropriate while your hand and graveyard have only one card total, you will be unable to. Any abilities that would trigger due to that reappropriate action don't.
reconstruct:
**Reconstruct** (cost) *(You may cast this from your graveyard for its reconstruct cost reduced by the mana value of a permanent you sacrifice as you cast it this way. Then exile this.)*
• Reconstruct represents three static abilities, one that functions while the card with reconstruct is in a graveyard, and two that functions while the spell with reconstruct is on the stack. “Reconstruct [cost]” means “You may cast this spell from your graveyard by paying [cost] and sacrificing a permanent rather than paying its mana cost,” “If you chose to pay this spell’s reconstruct cost, its total cost is reduced by an amount of generic mana equal to the sacrificed permanent’s mana value,” and "If the reconstruct cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else any time it would leave the stack." Casting a spell using its reconstruct ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2f–h.
• You choose which creature to sacrifice as you choose to pay a spell’s reconstruct cost (see rule 601.2b), and you sacrifice that creature as you pay the total cost (see rule 601.2h).
rediscover:
**Rediscover** a (quality) card *(Look at the top card of your library. You may reveal it and put it into your hand if it's an (quality) card. Otherwise, put it back or into your graveyard.)*
• To rediscover a [quality] card, look at the top card of your library. You may reveal it and put it into your hand if it's a [quality] card. Otherwise, put it into your graveyard or back on top of your library.
reprise:
**Reprise** (cost) *(As you cast an instant or sorcery spell, you may exile one card with reprise from your graveyard and pay its reprise cost. If you do, add its effects to that spell.)*
• Reprise is a static ability that functions while a card with reprise is in your graveyard. "Reprise (cost)" means "You may exile exactly one card with reprise from your graveyard as you cast an instant or sorcery spell. If you exile this card this way, copy this card's text box onto that spell and pay (cost) as an additional cost to cast that spell."
• You can't choose to reprise a card if you can't make the required choices, such as targets, for that card's instructions.
• You can't ever exile two or more cards with reprise for a single spell.
reverberate:
**Reverberate** (cost) *(When you cast this spell, copy it if you paid its reverberate cost. You may choose new targets for the copies.)*
• Reverberate is a keyword that represents a static ability and a triggered ability that function while the spell with reverberate is on the stack. "Reverberate (cost)" means "As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may pay (cost)," and "When you cast this spell, if you paid its reverberate cost, copy it. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for the copy."
• A spell is "reverberated" if it's a copy that was created by a reverberate ability.
revive:
**Revive** (cost) *((cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a token that's a copy of it except it has no mana cost. Revive only as a sorcery.)*
• Revive is an activated ability that functions while the card with revive is in a graveyard. "Revive (cost)" means "(cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a token that’s a copy of this card, except it has no mana cost. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery."
saga:
As a player’s precombat main phase begins, that player puts a lore counter on each Saga they control. This turn-based action doesn’t use the stack.
• If the number of lore counters on a Saga permanent is greater than or equal to its final chapter number, and it isn’t the source of a chapter ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, that Saga’s controller sacrifices it. This state-based action doesn’t use the stack.
salvage:
**salvage** a (quality) card *(Exile one from your graveyard until this creature leaves the battlefield. Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, put a card it salvaged into your hand.)*
• Salvage is a keyword action. To salvage a [quality] card, exile a card with that quality from your graveyard until the permanent that was the source of the salvage ability leaves the battlefield. That card is "salvaged" by that permanent.
• Whenever a creature that has one or more salvaged cards in exile deals combat damage to a player, that creature's controller puts one of those salvaged cards into its owner's hand.
shimmer:
**Shimmer** *(Whenever this creature attacks, create a tapped and attacking token that's a copy of it. Exile the token at the beginning of the end step.)*
• Shimmer is a triggered ability that may create one or more delayed triggered abilities. "Shimmer" means "Whenever this creature attacks, create a tapped and attacking token that’s a copy of it." and "Exile that token at the beginning of the end step."
• If a creature has multiple instances of shimmer, each triggers separately.
• The delayed trigger will retrigger at every end step. If the trigger is countered, or avoided by ending the turn, the token will remain on the battlefield and the ability will trigger on the next end step.
• Shimmer will only exile tokens created by its ability. Replacement effects such as Doubling Season cause shimmer to create two tokens, and both will be exiled. Effects that create a copy of those tokens, such as populate, will create a token will not attempt to be exiled every end step.
• If shimmer creates multiple tokens, each one will have its own end step exile trigger.
sleight:
**Sleight** *(You may cast this spell as though it had flash if you pay {1} more to cast it.)*
• "Sleight" means "You may cast this spell as though it had flash if you pay {1} more to cast it.
slipstream:
**Slipstream** *(This creature can’t be blocked as long as only creatures with slipstream are attacking.)*
• Slipstream is an evasion ability. A creature with slipstream can't be blocked as long as each attacking creature has slipstream.
• If creatures with and without slipstream are attacking and then each attacking creature without slipstream is removed from combat, creatures with slipstream can't be blocked. However, if blockers have already been declared, those creatures will still be blocked.
spirited:
**Spirited** *(When this creature enters the battlefield, you may activate one of its activated abilities without paying its cost.)*
• Spirited is a triggered ability. "Spirited" means "When this creature enters the battlefield, you may activate one of its abilities without paying that ability's cost."
• If a creature has spirited, its activated abilities whose cost includes the tap symbol or the untap symbol can be activated by its spirited ability even if that creature hasn’t been controlled by that player continuously since their most recent turn began.
• You may activate abilities that have costs that can't be paid while the permanent is on the battlefield. This is an exception to rule 113.6i.
• The ability that will be activated is chosen as the spirited ability resolves.
• Multiple instances of spirited trigger separately.
• If a permanent with spirited leaves the battlefield while the spirited ability is on the stack, spirited will use the last known information of the permanent to determine its abilities and if those abilities can be legally activated.
storied:
**Storied** *(Enchantments and legendary permanents are storied.)*
• The term "storied" refers to an object that has the legendary supertype or the enchantment card type.
submerge:
**Submerge** a card *(To submerge a card, exile it, then put it on the battlefield face down under its owner's control as a 2/2 creature.)*
• To submerge a card, exile it face up, then put it onto the battlefield face down under its owner's control as a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. That permanent is a submerged permanent as long as it remains face down. The effect defining its characteristics works while the card is face down and ends when it’s turned face up.
• Unlike manifest, a submerged card can not turn face up again on its own.
substantiate:
**Substantiate** a card *(Put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. You may turn it face up and cast it at any time for its mana cost if it isn't a creature.)*
• To substantiate a card, put it onto the battlefield face down under your control as a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. That permanent is a substantiated permanent as long as it remains face down. The effect defining its characteristics works while the card is face down and ends when it’s turned face up.
• Any time you have priority, you may exile and cast a substantiated permanent you control face up. This is a special action that doesn’t use the stack (see rule 116.2b). To do this, show all players that the card representing that permanent is a noncreature card, then cast that card. You still pay its costs, but this is not an alternate cost, so alternate costs can be paid. The effect defining its characteristics while it was face down ends, and it regains its normal characteristics. (If the card representing that permanent is a creature card, it doesn’t have a mana cost, or you are unable to cast it, it can’t be turned face up this way.)
tale:
**Tale** *(Cast a copy of this spell once while this creature is on the battlefield.)*
• A page card which has the Tale subtype as an alternate characteristic is called a tale card.
• As long as the permanent with the Tale is on the battlefield, and no Tales of that permanent been cast this game, the controller of permanent may cast a copy of the permanent's Tale.
• Casting a card's Tale works the same as casting any other spells, and additional and alternate costs may be paid for the spell.
• Once a permanent's Tale is cast, no Tales of that permanent can be cast for the rest of the game, even if the permanent somehow gains another Tale or temporarily loses its Tale.
• A Tale is not an ability of a card, but it is a property of the card, meaning the Tale of a permanent that has lost its abilities may be cast, and if another permanent becomes a copy of a permanent with a Tale, that Tale may be cast if that permanent hasn't had a Tale cast yet.
• If a Tale spell is copied, the copy is also a Tale. It has the alternative characteristics of the spell and not the normal characteristics of the card that includes the Tale spell. Any rule or effect that refers to a spell cast as an Tale refers to the copy as well.
tether:
**Tether** *(Then if you cast this from your hand, exile it tethered to a creature you control. When it dies, you may cast this from exile without paying its mana cost.)*
• Tether appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two abilities. The first is a spell ability that functions while the spell with tether is on the stack. The second is a static ability that functions while the card with tether is in the exile zone. "Tether" means "If this spell is represented by a card, you may exile this card tethered to a creature you control" and "When the creature this card is tethered to dies, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost."
• The term "tethered" describes the relationship between the card with tether while in the exile zone and the creature chosen when the spell represented by that card resolves.
• The card with tether remains tethered to the chosen creature as long as the card with tether remains exiled and the creature remains on the battlefield. The card remains tethered to that object even if it changes controller or stops being a creature, as long as it remains on the battlefield.
• If the permanent is put into a graveyard while not a creature, the 'dies' trigger of tether will still trigger.
tithe:
**Tithe** *(As you cast this spell, you may tap three artifacts and/or creatures you control.)* or *(When this creature enters the battlefield, you may tap three other artifacts and/or creatures you control.)*
• Tithe is an ability of some cards. It behaves differently on permanent and nonpermanent cards.
• On a permanent card, tithe is a triggered ability. "Tithe" on a permanent means "When this permanent enters the battlefield, you may tap three other untapped artifacts and/or creatures you control." Tapping the three permanents is a cost (see rule 118) and may be referred to as paying the permanent's tithe.
• On an instant or sorcery card, tithe is a static ability that functions while the spell with tithe is on the stack. "Tithe" on an instant or sorcery spell means "As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap three untapped artifacts and/or creatures you control." Paying an instant or sorcery spell's tithe cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2f–h. An instant or sorcery spell's tithe cost may also simply be referred to as its tithe.
torment:
**Torment** a player *(They lose 3 life unless they discard a card or sacrifice a nonland permanent.)*
• Torment is a keyword action. The player being tormented loses 3 life unless they discard a card or sacrifice a nonland card.
trial:
**Trial** X *(As you cast this spell, an opponent of your choice may pay X life. If they don't, they fail the trial.)*
• Trial is a static ability that functions while a spell with trial is on the stack. "Trial N" means "As you cast this spell, an opponent of your choice may pay N life. If that player doesn't, they fail the trial."
• Trials are paid or failed after targets have been chosen.
• Objects with trial have conditional effects that check "if the trial was failed," this condition is true if the opponent chosen as a result of the trial ability didn't pay life as specified by the object's trial ability.
vision:
**Vision** *(Whenever this or another creature enters the battlefield under your control, reveal the top card of your library. Then you may put that card into your graveyard.)*
• Vision is a triggered ability of some permanents. "Vision" means "When this permanent or another creature enters the battlefield under your control, reveal the top card of your library. Then you may put that card into your graveyard."
• Cards that are revealed this way are "envisioned" by the source of the vision ability that revealed them.
• Putting the card into your graveyard has no effect on if the card is envisioned or not.
voyage:
(a permanent) **voyages** *(If it isn’t blocking or targeted by another spell or ability, it phases out.)*
• Voyage is a keyword action. "(a permanent) voyages" means "If this permanent isn't blocking or the target of a spell or ability other than this one, it phases out and becomes a voyaging permanent until it phases in."
• A voyaging permanent "returns from voyage" when it phases in.
winnow:
**Winnow** *(Damage dealt to a creature with winnow also causes its controller to lose that much life.)*
• Damage dealt to a permanent with winnow causes that permanent's controller to lose that much life in addition to any other results of that damage. Multiple instances of winnow on a permanent are redundant.
additional:
**Additional Rules: Additional Libraries**
• Cards with the archive ability can create additional libraries. These libraries are separated from your starting library.
• An additional library with no cards in it ceases to exist. You will never be able to attempt to draw from an empty additional library.
• If a player would draw a card while they have multiple libraries and the draw effect doesn't specify a library, that player chooses which library they own to draw from. If a player would draw multiple cards at once, each card draw is chosen separately.
• If a cost or nonstatic effect would refer to a player's undefined library and that player has multiple libraries, that effect's controller chooses any library that player has upon resolution and the effect is applied to that library. If that effect has no controller, that player chooses the library instead.
***Example:*** Enlightened Tutor will shuffle the same library that was searched, and put the found card on top of that same library.
• Static abilities that refer to a player's undefined library apply to all of that player’s libraries instead.
***Example:*** Portent of the Long Winter says "Play with the top card of your library revealed." You will play with the top cards of all your libraries revealed.

**Additional Rules: Variable Modals**
• (When casting a spell....) If the spell is modal, the player announces the mode choice (see rule 700.2). If the number of choices has a currently undefined value, such as “Choose X,” or a value that may change during the process of casting the spell, such as “If this spell was kicked, choose any number instead”, the player chooses any number of modes. When the spell's legality is checked (rule 601.2e), if value is undefined or the value does not match the choices made, the spell is illegal.

perennial:
**Additional Rules: Perennial Triggers**
• Perennial triggers are triggered abilities formatted as
• Once each turn, when <condition>, you may <effect>
• These abilities will trigger as long as you have not chosen to do the effect after the may for this permanent this turn.
• If the permanent becomes a new object, it will reset if you have chosen to do the may effect this turn as well.
